tweets.content: @herahussain: Get women to design products & services end to end. End algorithmic bias. #IODC16 #opendatapic.twitter.com/4bwzR4covi
@OpenDataNation: Buenos Dias #iodc16! Let's talk about optimizing the business of government w data science. Deliver services effectively and efficiently.pic.twitter.com/vK3x9bxapZ

conference_notes:
A financial base is necessary to keep the whole infrastructure of open data initiatives. We need data management, the transmission of the knowledge to the citizens. How do we understand our data users? Is there any automatic way to do it? One way of knowing this is turning to these users, asking them for information (e.g. surveys).  Regarding the amount of data currently produced, how can we use it? How can we measure if the effort to analyze data collected 5 or 10 years ago is still worth it? We collect it as they thought it had to be collected. Analyzing older data is always worthy because the cost of the tools has decreased dramatically.
Historical data is really valuable to set trends. The new standard is a recodification of the old standard so all of  it is about integration
name: Data + Utilities
